w:r.w:t: It's important to understand that when developing on Base44, you define your data structures using JSON Schema (entities), and the platform handles the underlying database implementation (whether it's a relational database like PostgreSQL, a NoSQL database, or a hybrid). Therefore, this documentation will describe the
schema based on your entity definitions and the implied relationships.
The application's data model is built around a set of interconnected
, each representing a distinct type of information (e.g., users, tours, registrations). This design follows best practices for data modeling:
Data is organized into entities (tables/collections) with well-defined attributes (columns/fields) and relationships between them.

Entities are generally normalized to reduce data redundancy, ensuring data integrity. However, some denormalization is intentionally applied for performance (e.g., caching tourist_first_name within Registration) or to provide context without extra lookups.
Each attribute has a defined type (string, number, boolean, date, enum), enforced by the JSON Schema.
Base44 handles the actual database operations, indexing, scaling, and backups, allowing the application developer to focus on the logical data model.
Each entity automatically includes the following Base44-managed attributes, even if not explicitly in the JSON Schema:
created_date: Timestamp when the record was created.
updated_date: Timestamp when the record was last updated.
created_by: Email of the user who created the record.
Here are the custom entities and their specific attributes:
The User entity is fundamental and provided by Base44, handling authentication. Custom attributes extend its functionality.
user_type: (string, enum: 'system_admin', 'provider_admin', 'tourist', default: 'tourist') Specifies the application-specific role.
provider_id: (string) ID of the Provider if the user is a 'provider_admin' or associated 'tourist'.
is_active: (boolean, default: true) Whether the user account is active.
push_subscription: (object, nullable: true) Stores data for push notifications.
provider_name: (string) Name of the tour company (unique).
logo_url: (string) URL to the company's logo.
is_active: (boolean, default: true) Whether the provider is active.
Defines a reusable blueprint for a tour.
template_name: (string) Name of the tour template.
description: (string) Description of the tour template.
is_active: (boolean, default: true) Whether the template is active.
web_links: (array of objects) List of URLs and descriptions.
visibility: (string, enum: 'Public', 'Private') Controls visibility of custom tours derived from this template.
media_url: (string) URL of an image or video showcasing the template.
An actual instance of a tour, based on a TourTemplate and run by a Provider.
provider_id: (string) ID of the Provider running this tour.
tour_template_id: (string) ID of the TourTemplate this tour is based on.
tour_name: (string) Custom name for this specific tour instance.
start_date: (string, format: 'date') Start date for this tour instance.
end_date: (string, format: 'date') End date for this tour instance.
status: (string, enum: 'draft', 'published', 'completed', 'cancelled', default: 'draft') Current status of the tour.
join_code: (string) Unique, simple code for tourists to join.
max_tourists: (number, default: 5) Maximum number of tourists allowed.
remaining_tourists: (number) Number of remaining tourist spots.
group_chat_link: (string, format: 'uri') URL to a group chat for the tour.
web_links: (array of objects) Relevant web links for this custom tour.
media_url: (string) URL of an image or video for this custom tour.
Individual activities scheduled within a TourTemplate or CustomTour.
entry_date: (string, format: 'date-time') Date of the activity.
web_links: (array of strings) URLs related to the activity.
Pre-defined, reusable activity types for quick template creation.
activity_name: (string) Name of the default activity.
category: (string, enum: 'sightseeing', 'cultural', etc.) Category of the activity.
is_active: (boolean, default: true) Whether the activity is active.
Records a tourist's enrollment in a CustomTour.
provider_id: (string) ID of the Provider running the tour (denormalized for filtering).
status: (string, enum: 'pending', 'approved', 'rejected', 'cancelled', default: 'pending') Status of the registration.
notes: (string) Notes from tourist or provider admin.
document_type_name: (string) Name of the document type (e.g., "Passport", "Visa").
description: (string) Description of what it's for.
is_required: (boolean, default: false) Whether this document type is mandatory.
is_active: (boolean, default: true) Whether this document type is active.
Actual files uploaded by a tourist for a specific tour.
tourist_id: (string) ID of the User who uploaded it.
registration_id: (string) ID of the associated Registration.
document_type_name: (string) Name of the document type (denormalized).
file_name: (string) Original name of the uploaded file.
file_url: (string) URL of the uploaded file.
file_size: (number) Size of the file in bytes.
uploaded_by: (string) ID of the user who uploaded (tourist or provider admin).
Files uploaded by provider/system admin for a specific CustomTour, visible to all tourists on that tour.
file_name: (string) Original name of the uploaded file.
file_url: (string) URL of the uploaded file.
file_size: (number) Size of the file in bytes.
uploaded_by: (string) ID of the user who uploaded.
is_visible_to_tourists: (boolean, default: true) Whether tourists can see it.
template_document_id: (string) ID of the original TourTemplateDocument if inherited.
is_inherited_from_template: (boolean, default: false) Whether inherited from a template.
Files uploaded by system admin for a specific TourTemplate, which can be inherited by CustomTours.
file_name: (string) Original name of the uploaded file.
file_url: (string) URL of the uploaded file.
file_size: (number) Size of the file in bytes.
uploaded_by: (string) ID of the user who uploaded.
is_visible_to_tourists: (boolean, default: true) Whether tourists can see it.
Messages sent to all tourists registered for a specific CustomTour.
status: (string, enum: 'draft', 'published', default: 'draft') Status of the broadcast.
System-wide configuration settings, especially for payment-related defaults.
charge_per_tourist: (number, default: 0) Amount to charge per tourist beyond default capacity.
default_max_tourists: (number, default: 5) Default max tourists for new custom tours.
max_provider_admins: (number, default: 2) Max provider admins per company.
config_key: (string, default: 'default') Unique key to ensure a single config record.
Records changes or significant events related to a CustomTour for notification purposes.
updated_by: (string) ID of the user who made the update.
Tracks which Users have viewed specific TourUpdates.
custom_tour_id: (string) ID of the CustomTour (denormalized for query efficiency).
viewed_at: (string, format: 'date-time') When it was viewed.
Logs actions related to document management for notification purposes.
tourist_id: (string) ID of the User (tourist) involved.
provider_id: (string) ID of the Provider for this tour.
document_name: (string) Name of the document involved.
tourist_name: (string) Full name of the tourist (denormalized).
is_viewed_by_provider: (boolean, default: false) If the provider has seen this.
is_viewed_by_tourist: (boolean, default: false) If the tourist has seen this.
Records requests from a User (tourist) to become a provider_admin.
tourist_id: (string) ID of the User requesting.
provider_id: (string) ID of the Provider they want to join.
tourist_name: (string) Full name of the tourist (denormalized).
status: (string, enum: 'pending', 'approved', 'rejected', default: 'pending') Status of the request.
admin_notes: (string) Notes from the processing admin.
processed_by: (string) ID of the User (provider admin) who processed it.
Generic in-app notification system for users.
user_id: (string) ID of the recipient User.
related_entity_id: (string) ID of the related entity (e.g., Registration, Broadcast).
action_url: (string) URL to navigate to when clicked.
is_read: (boolean, default: false) Whether it has been read.
The relationships are implicitly managed through common ID fields:
One Provider can have many Users as provider_admins. (implied by User.provider_id)
Many Users (tourists) can be associated with a Provider through registrations or direct assignment. (implied by User.provider_id)
One TourTemplate can generate many CustomTours. (CustomTour.tour_template_id)
One CustomTour can have many Registrations. (Registration.custom_tour_id)
One User (tourist) can have many Registrations (for different tours). (Registration.tourist_id)
One CustomTour has many CalendarEntrys for its specific itinerary. (CalendarEntry.custom_tour_id)
One TourTemplate has many CalendarEntrys defining its base itinerary. (CalendarEntry.tour_template_id)
One DocumentType can be associated with many TouristDocuments. (TouristDocument.document_type_id)
One User can upload many TouristDocuments. (TouristDocument.tourist_id, uploaded_by)
One CustomTour can have many TourDocuments. (TourDocument.custom_tour_id)
One CustomTour can have many Broadcast messages. (Broadcast.custom_tour_id)
Complex many-to-many relationship tracking notifications and views.
One CustomTour can have many DocumentActivity records. (DocumentActivity.custom_tour_id)
One User (tourist or provider) can be involved in many DocumentActivity records. (DocumentActivity.tourist_id, provider_id)
A User can send a RoleChangeRequest to a Provider.
One User can receive many Notifications. (Notification.user_id)
Base44's managed database service likely handles automatic indexing for primary keys (id). Additionally, for optimal performance, the platform typically creates indexes on:
Attributes ending with _id (e.g., provider_id, custom_tour_id, tourist_id, tour_template_id, user_id) are almost always indexed as they are used for joins and filtering.
Attributes used often in filter conditions or list ordering (e.g., status in Registration and CustomTour, created_date, email, join_code, visibility).
Handled by the platform (e.g., Google OAuth).

Base44 entities inherently support granular access control. For example, User data is protected such that users can only view/edit their own records unless they have admin privileges. Access to CustomTour data is restricted based on provider_id for provider_admins.
Files are stored securely, with private files requiring signed URLs for access.

Modifying entity JSON Schemas (e.g., adding a new field, changing a type) is handled by Base44's data migration capabilities. The platform typically manages the necessary database alterations without requiring manual intervention from the developer.
This detailed schema provides a solid foundation for understanding the data structures and relationships that power your Tourlicity application.
